results.title: Spinning
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “How to form aluminium”.
Training film covering the different spinning processes used in forming aluminium. Shows factory floor demonstration of shaping techniques step by step with a recap of essentials.

results.title: L'homme de Neandertal
results.brief_description:
Episode 2 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).This episode takes us among a tribe of hunters and gatherers to find out more about their tool making techniques. We also discover how their society is affected by the Ice Age.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'angleterre D'elizabeth = Elizabethan England
results.brief_description:
Episode 16 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
Elizabeth I becomes Queen at 25. Her 39 articles lay the foundation for the Anglican church. Declared a heretic by the Pope, she also has to battle with Spain for naval supremacy. Other topics include: the beginning of circumnavigation, the voyages of Sr Francis Drake and the settlement of North America.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: L'age d'or des Provinces Unies = The golden age of the United Provinces
results.brief_description:
Episode 17 of Series “Il Etait Une Fois L’homme” (= “Once Upon a Time Man”).
The Republic Of The United Netherlands, consisted of the seven northern Netherlands provinces that won independence from Spain from 1568 to 1609, and it grew out of the Union of Utrecht (1579). For the next two centuries political control of the decentralized state shifted repeatedly between the province of Holland and the princes of Orange, who held the office of stadholder and represented a greater degree of centralization. This internal political stress, however, did not prevent the ascendancy of the Dutch Republic in the 17th century. In this ‘Golden Age’ the Republic developed a worldwide colonial empire far out of proportion to its resources. It also played a notable role in the coalition wars against Louis XIV of France. As the Republic emerged as a centre of international finance, it alsom served as a notable cultural centre. This episode also covers the establishment of the East India Company in 1594, the settlement of the Puritans in New Amsterdam (New York) and the Black Tulip scandal. Reference: Encyclopedia Britannica.

Credits: Director, writer, Albert Barille ; photography, Jean-Louis Karcher ; art direction, Philippe Landrot, Rene Borg ; graphic research, Jean Barbaud.
Cast: Roger Carel, Francine Laine, Pierre Trabaud, Henri Djanik [original French narration].

results.title: Jumpcut
results.brief_description: Two pieces of found footage were used to produce ‘Jumpcut’, a series of frames cut from the head and tails of various takes of a talking head shot for a 1970s industrial film or commercial; and a piece of 1950s/60s home movie footage depicting a jumping child interrupted by the perforation marks at the end of the reel. Both images are processed through the Cox Box. The loop of the jumping boy had developed, over time, a network of miniscule cracks in the emulsion which were further emphasised by the increased contrast of the processing and the slow motion.

results.title: Departure
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
In Departure, Ian Andrews has used mostly analogue techniques to evoke the decaying process that occurs in a film or photographic image over time, but in doing so, he has created an altogether different visual landscape in which different layers of image contest and compete against each other.
A small strip of found film footage of a man “departing” loops endlessly back and forth, and as it does so, the repeated actions of the man seem to physically alter the layers, the skin of film and image through which we watch this action take place. The figure is marking out the landscape by traversing it, by exiting the frame and leaving a ghostly trace of his presence - but it is the surface of the visual form itself that is left marked.

group_siblings.title: Data panic!
group_siblings.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio

results.title: Data panic!
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Close to trillion dollars a day changes hands globally in foreign exchange transactions. Only 15 percent corresponds to actual commodities or capital. The incredible speed of the New York Stock Exchange’s Superdot electronic order routing system means that the Dow Jones can swing back and forth by more than 50 points in a matter of minutes. These conditions bring about a condition known as “data panic” a feeling of insecurity and anxiety that engulfs every transfer of digital information, from international trade to electronic banking.

Data Panic combines images of computers, tape streamers, ATMs, terminals, workstations, printers, status indicators, traces and scans with computer animated icons, diagrams, pictograms, error messages, warnings, numbers, barcodes and binary digits. An advertorial style voice over narrates a non-sensical computer generated text interspersed with information technology advertising slogans.

results.title: Equalibrium
results.brief_description: One of the layers of this Equalibrium consists of an image of a Sufi like spinning dancer in a white lab coat. This out-take from an earlier film, Phonogramme, had somehow become splattered with a kind of mould that formed small flower like shapes in the frame. It is combined with a loop of hand-painted film which deteriorates slowly each time the loop repeats.
